questions.text:
A female with abdominal pain and bleeding per vagina with 3 months of amenorrhea. On examination her BP was 90/60mmHg. Which of the following statements is/are true about ectopic pregnancy?
1. Abdominal pain is the most common presenting symptom of ectopic pregnancy and may be present in at least 90% of the patients.
2. PID and sexually transmitted infections are a major risk factor.
3. Low values of progesterone are usually diagnostic of ectopic pregnancy, however there's no specific value to completely rule out or exclude ectopic pregnancy.
4. Oral methotrexate is a viable medical alternative to surgery in ectopic pregnancy patients presenting with shock or renal failure.
questions.solution:
1. Abdominal pain is the most common presenting symptom of ectopic pregnancy and may be present in at least 90% of the patients.
TRUE → Abdominal pain is the most frequent symptom and occurs in 90-100% of cases due to tubal distension or rupture.
It is often unilateral and sudden in onset, and may be associated with shoulder tip pain (due to diaphragmatic irritation from hemoperitoneum).

2. PID and sexually transmitted infections are a major risk factor.
TRUE → Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) due to Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a major risk factor for tubal damage, leading to ectopic pregnancy.
Other risk factors include:

  • Smoking
  • IVF
  • Tubal surgery
  • Previous ectopic pregnancy

3. Low values of progesterone are usually diagnostic of ectopic pregnancy, however, there's no specific value to completely rule out or exclude ectopic pregnancy.
TRUE → Serum progesterone levels <5 ng/mL suggest a nonviable pregnancy (ectopic or miscarriage).
However, progesterone alone cannot definitively diagnose or exclude ectopic pregnancy.

4. Oral methotrexate is a viable medical alternative to surgery in ectopic pregnancy patients presenting with shock or renal failure.
FALSE → Methotrexate is contraindicated in hemodynamically unstable patients or those with renal failure.
Surgical intervention (laparotomy or laparoscopy) is required in patients presenting with:

  • Ruptured ectopic pregnancy
  • Hemodynamic instability (shock, BP <90/60 mmHg)
  • Severe pain or hemoperitoneum

Key Takeaway:

Abdominal pain is the most common symptom in 90-100% of cases. PID and STIs are major risk factors. Low progesterone levels suggest ectopic pregnancy but cannot definitively rule it out. Oral methotrexate is contraindicated in shock or renal failure.

choices.text: Increase in systolic and diastolic blood pressure after 6 weeks
Peripheral resistance to insulin leading to hyperinsulinemia
Increased plasma volume and RBC mass

questions.text: Which of the following is not a physiological change seen in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Choice A. Increase in systolic and diastolic blood pressure after 6 weeks
FALSE → In normal pregnancy, BP decreases due to systemic vasodilation caused by progesterone, relaxin, and nitric oxide.
BP typically decreases until mid-pregnancy (24 weeks) and then gradually returns to baseline by term.
If BP increases early in pregnancy, suspect chronic hypertension or gestational hypertension developing later.

Incorrect choices explanation :

Choice B. Peripheral resistance to insulin leading to hyperinsulinemia
TRUE → Pregnancy is a diabetogenic state due to increased insulin resistance.
Hormones responsible:

  • Human placental lactogen (hPL)
  • Progesterone, cortisol, prolactin
    • To compensate for insulin resistance, pancreatic β-cells increase insulin secretion, leading to hyperinsulinemia.

Choice C. Fasting hypoglycemia and postprandial hyperglycemia
TRUE →

  • Fasting hypoglycemia → Due to increased glucose uptake by the fetus and placenta.
  • Postprandial hyperglycemia → Due to increased insulin resistance, leading to delayed glucose disposal.
    • This "accelerated starvation" ensures a continuous glucose supply to the fetus.

Choice D. Increased plasma volume and RBC mass
TRUE → Plasma volume increases by 40-50% and RBC mass by 20-30%, leading to:

  • Physiological anemia of pregnancy (due to dilutional effect).
  • Increased oxygen-carrying capacity to meet fetal demands.

Key Takeaway:

Blood pressure decreases in early pregnancy due to systemic vasodilation and reaches its lowest point around 24 weeks. Pregnancy induces insulin resistance with hyperinsulinemia, causes fasting hypoglycemia and postprandial hyperglycemia, and leads to increased plasma volume and RBC mass, contributing to physiological anemia.

questions.text: Instrument assisted delivery is not indicated in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Choice D. Cephalopelvic Disproportion (CPD)
CONTRAINDICATION → CPD means the fetal head is too large or the maternal pelvis is too small for vaginal delivery.

Instrument-assisted delivery is contraindicated because it cannot overcome a mechanical obstruction.
Management → Cesarean section is the safest mode of delivery.

Incorrect choices explanation :

Choice A. Fetal Distress
TRUE INDICATION → Instrument-assisted delivery (vacuum/forceps) can be used in non-reassuring fetal status (e.g., bradycardia, late decelerations) to expedite delivery and prevent fetal hypoxia.

Choice B. Maternal Exhaustion
TRUE INDICATION → If the mother is unable to push effectively due to exhaustion, forceps or vacuum assistance can shorten the second stage and reduce maternal morbidity.

Choice C. Prolonged Second Stage of Labour
TRUE INDICATION → Instrumental delivery can help if there is adequate descent and engagement.

Key Takeaway:

Instrument-assisted delivery is contraindicated in cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) because it cannot overcome mechanical obstruction. It is indicated for fetal distress, maternal exhaustion, and prolonged second stage when descent and engagement are adequate. Cesarean section is the preferred mode of delivery in CPD.

questions.text: A 14 year old came with complaints of acute urinary retention. She has not attended menarche and has cyclic abdominal pain. On genital examination bluish bulge is seen. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Choice B. Imperforate Hymen (Correct Answer)
Classic presentation → Primary amenorrhea, cyclic pain, urinary retention, and bluish bulging hymen.
Cause: Failure of hymenal perforation during fetal development.
Complications: Hematocolpos (accumulation of menstrual blood in the vagina), leading to acute urinary retention due to compression of the urethra.
Management: Cruciate or elliptical hymenotomy to relieve obstruction.

Incorrect choices explanation :

Choice A. Transverse Vaginal Septum
Can also cause primary amenorrhea and cyclic abdominal pain, but usually no bluish bulge is seen.

May present with high vaginal obstruction, and often requires surgical resection.

Choice C. Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) Syndrome
Primary amenorrhea due to Müllerian agenesis (absence of uterus & upper 2/3 of the vagina).
No hematocolpos or bluish bulge since menstruation does not occur.
Normal ovarian function and secondary sexual characteristics are present.

Choice D. OHVIRA (Obstructed Hemivagina and Ipsilateral Renal Anomaly)
Also called Herlyn-Werner-Wunderlich syndrome.
Usually presents with unilateral hematocolpos/hematometra due to a double uterus (uterine didelphys) with one obstructed hemivagina.
Associated with renal anomalies, but typically no bluish bulge on genital exam.

Key Takeaway:

Imperforate hymen presents with primary amenorrhea, cyclic abdominal pain, urinary retention, and a bluish bulging hymen due to hematocolpos. Management is hymenotomy to relieve obstruction. Other causes like MRKH, transverse vaginal septum, and OHVIRA do not show a bluish bulge on examination.

questions.text: Which of the following is the smallest pelvic diameter at the brim?
questions.solution:
Choice A. Obstetric Conjugate (Correct Answer)
Smallest pelvic diameter at the brim through which the fetal head must pass.
Measurement: Distance from sacral promontory to the thickest point of the pubic symphysis (posterior surface).
Clinical Importance: Determines if the fetus can engage in the pelvis.
Formula: Obstetric conjugate = Diagonal conjugate - 1.5 to 2 cm.
Normal value: ≥ 10 cm (if < 10 cm, suggests cephalopelvic disproportion). 

Incorrect choices explanation :

Choice B. Diagonal Conjugate
Measured clinically via vaginal examination from sacral promontory to the inferior border of the pubic symphysis.

Largest measurable conjugate diameter, but not the true limiting factor for engagement.
Normal value: ~ 11.5-13 cm.

Choice C. True Conjugate (Anatomical conjugate)
Distance from sacral promontory to the upper border of the pubic symphysis.
Not clinically measurable, but can be estimated from the diagonal conjugate.
Normal value: ~11 cm.

Choice D. Anatomical Conjugate
Same as the True Conjugate but often confused in terminology.
Not the smallest diameter at the brim.

Key Takeaway:

The obstetric conjugate is the smallest pelvic diameter at the brim and is critical for fetal head engagement. It is measured from the sacral promontory to the thickest part of the pubic symphysis and is approximately 10 cm. It is smaller than the diagonal conjugate by 1.5-2 cm.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, G2P1L1, comes for a quadruple test at 16 weeks. Which of the following is not included in the quadruple test?
questions.solution:
Choice A. Dimeric inhibin BX (Correct Answer - Not included in the quadruple test)
The quadruple test measures Dimeric Inhibin A, not Inhibin BX.
Inhibin BX is not a standard marker used in prenatal screening.

Incorrect choices explanation :

Choice B. Unconjugated Estriol (uE3)
Included in the quadruple test.
Produced by the fetal adrenal gland and liver.
Low levels are seen in trisomy 18 and 21.

Choice C. Alpha-Fetoprotein (AFP)
Included in the quadruple test.
Produced by the fetal liver.
High AFP → Suggests neural tube defects, abdominal wall defects.
Low AFP → Suggests trisomy 21 and 18.

Choice D. Beta-hCG
Included in the quadruple test.
High β-hCG → Suggests trisomy 21.
Low β-hCG → Suggests trisomy 18.

Key Takeaway:

The quadruple test at 16-18 weeks includes AFP, unconjugated estriol (uE3), β-hCG, and inhibin A. Dimeric inhibin B is NOT included. This screening test assesses the risk of trisomy 21, trisomy 18, and neural tube defects.

questions.text: Early onset preeclampsia is defined before:
questions.solution:
Early-onset preeclampsia is defined as preeclampsia occurring before 34 weeks of gestation.
It is associated with:
Higher maternal and fetal complications
More severe placental dysfunction
Higher risk of fetal growth restriction (FGR) and preterm birth

Late-onset preeclampsia occurs at or after 34 weeks, often with milder placental involvement.

Choice D) 34 weeks - Correct answer; Early-onset preeclampsia = before 34 weeks.

Incorrect choices explanation :

Choice A) 28 weeks - Too early; severe cases may present before 28 weeks, but early-onset preeclampsia is defined before 34 weeks, not 28 weeks.

Choice B) 30 weeks - Incorrect, as the threshold for early-onset preeclampsia is before 34 weeks.

Choice C) 32 weeks - Still incorrect; early-onset preeclampsia includes cases before 34 weeks, not just before 32 weeks.

Key Takeaway:

Early-onset preeclampsia occurs before 34 weeks and is linked to higher maternal and fetal complications, severe placental dysfunction, fetal growth restriction (FGR), and preterm birth. Late-onset preeclampsia occurs at or after 34 weeks.

Reference: www.ncbi.com

choices.text: Term and preterm babies irrespective of birth weight
Vigorous term and preterm babies requiring resuscitation
All term babies born at 37 weeks

questions.text: When is delayed cord clamping done?
questions.solution:
Delayed cord clamping (DCC) is recommended for both term and preterm infants, regardless of birth weight, unless there are contraindications.

Definition: Clamping the umbilical cord ≥30-60 seconds after birth.
Benefits:
Increases neonatal hemoglobin and iron stores
Reduces risk of anemia in infancy
Enhances circulatory stability in preterm neonates
Decreases incidence of intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) and necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) in preterms

Choice A) Term and preterm babies irrespective of birth weight
Correct answer; DCC is beneficial in both term and preterm babies.

Incorrect choices explanation :

Choice B) Vigorous term and preterm babies requiring resuscitation
Delayed cord clamping is not recommended for babies needing immediate resuscitation, as immediate intervention takes priority.

Choice C) Vigorous term babies requiring resuscitation
Again, if the baby requires immediate resuscitation, DCC is not done, as prompt resuscitative measures are necessary.

Choice D) All term babies born at 37 weeks
DCC is not limited to term infants; it is beneficial in both term and preterm neonates, making this option incorrect.

Key Takeaway:

Delayed cord clamping (DCC) is recommended for both term and preterm infants, regardless of birth weight. It improves neonatal hemoglobin levels, reduces anemia risk, and enhances circulatory stability in preterms. DCC is not performed if immediate resuscitation is needed.

choices.text: Passive movement of head due to untwisting of neck
Movement of the head by 1/8th of the circle due to torsion
Stretching of the vulval outlet by the head
External rotation after delivery of shoulder

questions.solution:
Choice A) Passive movement of head due to untwisting of neck (Correct Answer)

  • Restitution refers to the passive movement of the fetal head after delivery due to the untwisting of the neck.
  • This occurs because, during labor, the fetal head undergoes internal rotation while the body remains in its original position. Once the head is delivered, it rotates back to align with the shoulders. 

Incorrect choices explanation :

Choice B) Movement of the head by 1/8th of the circle due to torsion ( Incorrect)

  • The fetal head undergoes internal rotation during labor by 1/8th of a circle (45 degrees) or 1/4th of a circle (90 degrees) depending on the position.
  • However, restitution is not an active movement due to torsion but a passive correction once the head is delivered.

Choice C) Stretching of the vulval outlet by the head ( Incorrect)

  • This describes crowning, not restitution.
  • Crowning occurs when the largest diameter of the fetal head stretches the perineum before full delivery.

Choice D) External rotation after delivery of shoulder ( Incorrect)

  • After restitution, external rotation (or "shoulder rotation") happens when the shoulders align with the pelvis.
  • This is a separate movement from restitution.

Key Takeaway:

Restitution is the passive movement of the fetal head after delivery due to the untwisting of the neck. It occurs as the head realigns with the fetal shoulders after undergoing internal rotation during labor.

questions.text: A 35-year-old P2L2 woman presents with malodorous vaginal discharge and normal cervix. The whiff test is positive. What is this condition?
questions.solution:
Choice C) Bacterial Vaginosis (Correct Answer)

  • Bacterial vaginosis (BV) is a common cause of malodorous, thin, gray-white vaginal discharge.
  • The whiff test (positive amine test) is diagnostic for BV. It involves adding 10% KOH to vaginal secretions, which releases a fishy odor due to amines (putrescine, cadaverine, and trimethylamine).
  • Other diagnostic criteria include Amsel’s criteria:
    1. Thin, homogenous discharge
    2. Vaginal pH >4.5
    3. Clue cells on microscopy
    4. Positive whiff test

Incorrect choices explanation :

Choice A) Candida ( Incorrect)

  • Candida causes thick, white, curdy vaginal discharge with intense itching.
  • The whiff test is negative in Candida infections.
  • Microscopy shows pseudohyphae and budding yeast on KOH mount.

Choice B) Chlamydia ( Incorrect)

  • Chlamydia trachomatis can cause cervicitis, leading to mucopurulent cervical discharge.
  • The cervix is often inflamed and friable on examination.
  • Whiff test is negative. Diagnosis is by NAAT (Nucleic Acid Amplification Test).

Choice D) Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) (Incorrect)

  • PID presents with pelvic pain, fever, cervical motion tenderness, and mucopurulent discharge.
  • It is usually caused by gonorrhea and chlamydia.
  • Whiff test is not a diagnostic feature.

Key Takeaway:

Bacterial vaginosis (BV) is characterized by malodorous, thin, gray-white discharge with a positive whiff test (fishy odor on adding KOH). It is diagnosed using Amsel’s criteria and treated with metronidazole or clindamycin.

questions.text: A 26 year old P1L1 presents with abdominal pain. She has a past history of rheumatic heart disease for which she has undergone mitral valve replacement surgery and is on oral tablet Warfarin 3 mg OD. On examination 14 weeks abdominal mass was felt. On USG, 8*6 cm unilocular cyst with reticular pattern was observed in the left ovary. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Choice B) Repeat USG after 6-12 weeks ( Correct Answer)

  • The unilocular cyst with reticular pattern at 14 weeks is most likely a luteal cyst or simple ovarian cyst, which are physiological in pregnancy.
  • Most functional cysts resolve spontaneously by the second trimester, hence repeat USG is the best approach unless there are concerning features (e.g., solid areas, septations, or rapid growth).

Incorrect choices explanation :

Choice A) Measure CA-125 ( Incorrect)

  • CA-125 is not a reliable marker in pregnancy because its levels can be physiologically elevated in the first trimester, leading to false positives.
  • It is used for evaluating suspicious adnexal masses, but this cyst lacks high-risk features.

Choice C) Surgical intervention ( Incorrect)

  • Surgery is only indicated if the cyst is >10 cm, rapidly growing, has solid components, or causes complications (torsion, rupture, or persistent pain).
  • As the cyst is unilocular and 8 × 6 cm, conservative management with follow-up is preferable.
  • Surgery in early pregnancy carries a risk of miscarriage.

Choice D) MRI pelvis ( Incorrect)

  • MRI is reserved for cases where malignancy is suspected (e.g., complex cyst with solid areas, ascites, or abnormal Doppler flow).
  • This cyst does not meet those criteria.

Key Takeaway:

A unilocular cyst with a reticular pattern in early pregnancy is most likely physiological (corpus luteum/luteal cyst)and usually resolves spontaneously. Repeat USG after 6–12 weeks is the preferred management unless malignancy is suspected.

questions.text: An athlete with a BMI of 17.5 kg/m2 presents with secondary amenorrhea and primary infertility. Her laboratory investigations reveal FSH 2; LH 0.3; TSH 1.2. Prolactin 20 ng/ml. What is the underlying cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
• Low BMI (17.5 kg/m²) suggests functional hypothalamic amenorrhea (FHA), often seen in athletes due to energy deficiency.
  • Low FSH (2 mIU/mL) and very low LH (0.3 mIU/mL) indicate a hypogonadotropic state (impaired GnRH secretion).
  • Normal TSH and prolactin rule out thyroid or prolactin-related causes.

Diagnosis: Functional Hypothalamic Amenorrhea (FHA) due to energy deficiency and excessive exercise, leading to Hypogonadotropic Hypogonadism (HH).

Incorrect choices explanation :

  • Choice A) Primary ovarian failure - Would show high FSH & LH (Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism).
  • Choice C) Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism - Incorrect because FSH & LH are low, not high.
  • Choice D) Normogonadotropic normogonadism - Incorrect, as FSH & LH are below normal.

Key Takeaway:

This case represents functional hypothalamic amenorrhea (FHA) due to low energy availability in an athlete, leading to hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (low FSH and LH).

questions.text: A couple presents with infertility even with 2 years of unprotected intercourse. The seminal analysis reveals volume of 2 ml, concentration of 4 million/ml,progressive motility of 55%, and morphology 45%. The wife's hormone levels were normal with bilateral spillage of dye from both fallopian tubes on HSG. What percentage of couples can be attributed to unexplained infertility?
questions.solution:
• Unexplained infertility is diagnosed when ovulation, tubal patency, and semen parameters are normal, yet conception does not occur.
  • Studies estimate that 20-30% of infertile couples have unexplained infertility, with most guidelines citing ~25% as the accepted prevalence.
  • In this case, sperm concentration is low (oligozoospermia), which suggests male factor infertility, rather than unexplained infertility.

However, if all parameters (including semen analysis) were normal, the couple would fall under unexplained infertility, which accounts for 25% of cases.

Key Takeaway:

Unexplained infertility accounts for approximately 25% of infertility cases, diagnosed when standard fertility evaluations are normal but conception does not occur.

questions.text: Which of the ovarian structures is responsible for the following finding?
questions.solution:
• The corpus luteum is the remnant of the Graafian follicle after ovulation.
  • It is responsible for the production of progesterone, which is essential for maintaining the luteal phase and supporting early pregnancy.
  • The reference image likely depicts the corpus luteum, which appears as a highly vascularized, yellowish structure in the ovary.

Choice D) Corpus luteum - Correct. It is responsible for progesterone secretion, crucial for luteal phase and early pregnancy.

Incorrect Options:

Option A) Secondary follicle - Contains antrum formation but does not produce significant progesterone.

Option B) Theca interna - Produces androgens but does not form the corpus luteum.

Option C) Granulosa cell - Converts androgens to estrogens but does not produce large amounts of progesterone post-ovulation.

Key Takeaway:

The corpus luteum is the ovarian structure responsible for progesterone production after ovulation, playing a critical role in maintaining the luteal phase and supporting early pregnancy.

Reference: https://images.app.goo.gl/bkrJFHYdhNyJx1gU7

choices.text: Co-testing (pap and Hr HPV) every 5 years starting at 25 years
Pap smear every 3 years, starting at 21 yrs
Hr HPV testing every 5 years starting at 30 yrs
Pap smear every 5 years starting at 21 years

questions.text: Dr. Priya is conducting a talk on the screening of cervical cancer with Pap smear. She works in a clinic in a low resource setting and she was planning to screen a woman in her 20s. Which of the following is true regarding cervical cancer screening guidelines in her workplace?
questions.solution:
• According to American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG), USPSTF, and WHO guidelines, Pap smear (cytology) is recommended every 3 years starting at 21 years, regardless of HPV status.
  • In low-resource settings, WHO recommends Pap smear every 3 years due to cost-effectiveness and availability.
  • Co-testing (Pap + HPV) is not recommended before 30 years due to transient HPV infections in younger women.
  • Choice B) Pap smear every 3 years, starting at 21 years → WHO and ACOG recommend this in low-resource settings.

Incorrect choices explanation :

  • Choice A) Co-testing (Pap + HrHPV) every 5 years starting at 25 years → Incorrect. Co-testing starts at 30 years, not 25 years.
  • Choice C) Hr HPV testing every 5 years starting at 30 years → Partially correct, but not relevant for women in their 20s.
  • Choice D) Pap smear every 5 years starting at 21 years → Incorrect. The correct interval is every 3 years.

Key Takeaway:

In low-resource settings, Pap smear every 3 years starting at 21 years is the recommended screening method for cervical cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following does not constitute as a germ cell tumor?
questions.solution:
Juvenile Granulosa cell tumor (Choice C): A sex cord-stromal tumor, not a germ cell tumor. It arises from granulosa cells and is associated with increased estrogen levels, leading to precocious puberty in young girls.

Incorrect choices explanation :

  • Yolk sac tumor (Choice A): A germ cell tumor derived from the extraembryonic yolk sac, commonly seen in young females and associated with elevated AFP levels.
  • Dysgerminoma (Choice B): The most common malignant germ cell tumor of the ovary, associated with LDH elevation and found in young women.
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma (Choice D): A rare and aggressive germ cell tumor of the ovary, distinct from gestational choriocarcinoma, and associated with β-hCG elevation.

Thus, the correct answer is C (Juvenile Granulosa cell tumor), as it belongs to the sex cord-stromal tumor category, not the germ cell tumor category.

Key Takeaway:

Juvenile Granulosa cell tumor is a sex cord-stromal tumor, not a germ cell tumor, making it the correct answer.
